{{Infobox television | show_name = Ace Ventura Jr.: Pet Detective | image = Ace Ventura Jr - Pet Detective.png | image_size = | image_alt = | caption = | genre = | creator = | based_on = {{basedon|Characters|Jack Bernstein}} | writer = | screenplay = Jeffery Sank
Jason Heimberg
Justin Heimberg
[[David Mickey Evans]] | story = Jeffery Sank
Jason Heimberg
Justin Heimberg | director = [[David Mickey Evans]] | starring = [[Josh Flitter]]
[[Emma Lockhart]]
[[Ann Cusack]]
[[Cullen Douglas]]
[[Art LaFleur]]
Austin Rogers
[[Reed Alexander]]
[[Ralph Waite]] | narrated = | music = [[Laura Karpman]] | country = United States | language = English | num_episodes = | producer = [[James G. Robinson]]
David Robinson | editor = Danny Saphire | cinematography = [[Mark Irwin]] | runtime = 93 minutes | company = [[Morgan Creek Productions]] | distributor = [[Warner Home Video]] | budget = | network = [[Cartoon Network]] | first_aired = {{Start date|2009|3|1}} | last_aired = | preceded_by = | followed_by = | website = }} '''''Ace Ventura Jr.: Pet Detective''''' (also known as '''''Ace Ventura Jr.''''' or '''''Ace Ventura 3''''')is the third and final [[Ace Ventura]] film. It is a [[direct-to-video]] spin-off sequel to the films ''[[Ace Ventura: Pet Detective]]'' and ''[[Ace Ventura: When Nature Calls]]'', without involvement from either lead actor [[Jim Carrey]] nor writer [[Steve Oedekerk]]. The film began production in Orlando, [[Florida]] on September 17, 2007, was directed by [[David M. Evans]] and written by Jeff Sank, Jason Heimberg, and Justin Heimberg.[http://www.canmag.com/nw/8327-josh-flitter-ace-ventura Alrighty Then! Josh Flitter for Third Ace Ventura][http://www.movieweb.com/news/16/14116.php Jeff Sank, Jason Heimberg and Justin Heimberg On Ace Ventura Duty] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070713070837/http://www.movieweb.com/news/16/14116.php |date=July 13, 2007 }} ==Plot== {{cleanup|section|date=November 2010}} Ventura must follow in his father's (''Ace Ventura Sr.'s'') footsteps to save his mother from going to jail. In the beginning, Ace is chasing a woman. He catches her, and walks straight into the alligator habitat. Later in a dream Ace sees a panda ,Ting Tang, being captured. Soon his mother is blamed for the theft. She asks if she can make one phone call. She calls Rex Ventura, Ace's paternal grandfather. Rex tells Ace the history of the Ventura Family and their relationship with animals. Rex Ventura is an elderly man with several animals such as a cat, a turtle and a dog which Ace thinks is dead. At his mother's trial, Ace Jr. presents evidence that proves his mother couldn't have committed the crime of stealing Ting-Tang the panda; however, the Ranger (the one that Ace doesn't like), dismisses the evidence and Ace's mother is ultimately taken to jail. At school the next day, Ace hears that many of his classmates, including his crush, Laura ([[Emma Lockhart]]), have brutally murdered their pets. Laura has killed her pet emerald green koi fish. Ace goes to school the next day and talks to a boy nicknamed A-Plus. A-Plus has a hidden lab in his locker, which Ace uses as his office. They believe a scientist named Dr. Sickinger ([[Cullen Douglas]]), who's also somewhat insane, is the panda thief, primarily because he created a website called "PandaHub." However, Sickinger is ultimately proven innocent and ends up working with the kids to find out who the real culprit is. The kids discover that Sickinger used to work for Quenton Pennington Jr. ([[Reed Alexander]]), a rich kid whose family motto is, "What a Pennington wants a Pennington gets." In the end Ace finds that Pennington Sr. ([[Brian Patrick Clarke]]) stole Ting Tang, as well as a bunch of other famous animals (Tabby the tabby, Princess the lap dog, Freedom the hawk, and Callypso the magic horse), and that Pennington Jr. stole Ace's classmates' pets. His mother's name is finally cleared and is rewarded for his heroics. At this point in the movie, it is also discovered that Ace has been using extreme hallucinogens such as LSD throughout the whole film, and that the entire story is just a figment of Ace's imagination whilst high. Ace's father does not appear in this film. Until Rex comes in, whenever Ace Jr. would ask his mom about his dad, she would simply tell him that he had disappeared on a business trip when he was a baby and wouldn't go into any greater detail. However, before she's taken to jail (before Rex comes in), she elaborates on what happened to Ace Sr.: when their son was still just a baby, Ace had rescued a group of endangered animals and while flying them to safety, the airplane that they were in disappeared somewhere over the [[Bermuda Triangle]], and Ace Ventura Sr. was never seen or heard from again after that. ==Cast== * [[Josh Flitter]] as Ace Ventura Jr., son of [[Ace Ventura|Ace Ventura Sr.]] * [[Emma Lockhart]] as Laura * Austin Rogers as Arnold Plushinsky/A-Plus * [[Art LaFleur]] as Russell Hollander * [[Reed Alexander]] as Quenton Pennington Jr. * [[William Haze]] as Magician * [[Cullen Douglas]] as Dr. Sickinger * [[Ann Cusack]] as Melissa Robinson Ventura, wife of Ace Ventura Sr., and mother of Ace Ventura Jr. She was previously played by [[Courteney Cox]] in the first film. * [[Ralph Waite]] as Rex Ventura, father of Ace Ventura Sr., and grandfather of Ace Ventura Jr. * Jesse Kozel as Neighbor * [[Brian Patrick Clarke]] as Mr. Pennington * [[Aubrey Peeples]] as Daniella * Ashley Milchman as Emo Kid #1 * Brooke Milchman as Emo Kid #2 ==Reception== The film received largely negative critical reception. ''[[Film Threat]]'' gave the film 1½ stars out of 5, stating "It's disappointing that this is the next, and most likely final step of the Ace Ventura franchise."{{cite web |url=http://www.filmthreat.com/reviews/11621/ |title=ACE VENTURA JR.: PET DETECTIVE (DVD) |author= |date=March 12, 2009 |work=[[Film Threat]] |publisher= |accessdate=July 28, 2012}} ''[[Common Sense Media]]'' gave it 2 out of 5 stars, summing the film up as a "Funny, animal-loving kid lost in crude script."{{cite web |url=http://www.commonsensemedia.org/movie-reviews/ace-ventura-pet-detective-jr |title=Ace Ventura Pet Detective Jr. |author= |date=February 25, 2009 |work=[[Common Sense Media]] |publisher= |accessdate=July 28, 2012}} ''Movie Metropolis'' also gave a negative review, stating "What was pretty juvenile in the first place becomes literally juvenile in this straightforward kids' romp. If I were a kid, I might like it. But I'm not a kid, and I didn't."{{cite web|url=http://moviemet.com/review/ace-ventura-jr-pet-detective-dvd-review |title=ACE VENTURA JR.: PET DETECTIVE - DVD review |author=Puccio, John J |date=February 18, 2009 |work=moviemet.com |publisher= |accessdate=July 28, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120323125307/http://moviemet.com/review/ace-ventura-jr-pet-detective-dvd-review |archivedate=March 23, 2012 }} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|0844029}} * {{Amg movie|358562}} * {{tcmdb title|id=732934}} {{Ace Ventura}} {{David M. Evans}} [[Category:Ace Ventura]] [[Category:American comedy films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:2000s comedy films]] [[Category:American detective films]] [[Category:Television sequel films]] [[Category:Morgan Creek Productions films]] [[Category:Warner Bros. direct-to-video films]] [[Category:Film spin-offs]] [[Category:Films shot in Florida]] [[Category:2009 direct-to-video films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Direct-to-video comedy films]] [[Category:Films directed by David M. Evans]] [[Category:American sequel films]]

{{Infobox company | name = Adare Productions | logo = Adare Productions logo.jpg | industry = Entertainment television | location = [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]] | founded = 1993 }} '''Adare Productions''' is an [[Republic of Ireland|Irish]] entertainment television production company. It has produced numerous television shows which have been broadcast in Ireland, including ''[[Delegation (TV)|Delegation]]'', ''[[Livin' with Lucy]]'', ''[[Hanging with Hector]]'', ''[[The Fame Game]]'',<ref name="Fame Game calls for Sligo fanatics">{{cite web|url=http://archives.tcm.ie/sligoweekender/2003/05/20/story12542.asp |title=Fame Game calls for Sligo fanatics |date=2003-05-20 |accessdate=2008-10-22 |publisher=''[[Sligo Weekender]]'' |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110622095618/http://archives.tcm.ie/sligoweekender/2003/05/20/story12542.asp |archivedate=2011-06-22 |df= }}</ref> and ''[[Fáilte Towers]]'' for [[Raidió Teilifís Éireann|Radio Telefís Éireann]], and ''Glas Vegas'' and ''[[Underdogs (Irish TV series)|Underdogs]]'' for [[TG4]]. The company is credited with discovering numerous television presenters.
==Origin and further details== Adare Productions was established in 1993.<ref name="Home">[http://www.adareproductions.ie/ "Home"]. Adare Productions. Accessed 29 April 2009.</ref> The company claims to have produced at least fourteen different entertainment series, eleven young peoples' series, four different lifestyle series, more than three hundred hours of live studio programmes and more than forty hours of music programmes.<ref name="TV Productions">[http://www.adareproductions.ie/tv-productions.asp "TV Productions"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090509235532/http://www.adareproductions.ie/tv-productions.asp |date=2009-05-09 }}. Adare Productions. Accessed 29 April 2009.</ref> It has discovered presenters such as [[Caroline Morahan]], [[Lucy Kennedy]] and [[Hector Ó hEochagáin]].<ref name="Fashion Extravaganza With Caroline Morahan!">[http://www.rte.ie/tv/theafternoonshow/1080725.html "Fashion Extravaganza With Caroline Morahan!"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080504085204/http://www.rte.ie/tv/theafternoonshow/1080725.html |date=May 4, 2008 }}. RTÉ. Accessed 29 April 2009.</ref>
Lynda McQuaid has been executive producer on ''Fáilte Towers'' and producer and director on ''The Apprentice''.<ref name="The reality is Big Brother's days are truly numbered...">{{cite web|url=http://www.independent.ie/entertainment/tv-radio/the-reality-is-big-brothers-days-are-truly-numbered-1436405.html|title=The reality is Big Brother's days are truly numbered...|date=2008-07-21|accessdate=2009-04-29|publisher=''[[Irish Independent]]''}}</ref>
==Recent television credits== ===''Underdogs'' (2006)=== ''Underdogs'' was a television programme broadcast on TG4. It featured "underdog" players of [[Gaelic games]], focusing on those individuals who had never played senior inter-county [[Gaelic football|football]] or [[hurling]] or received a nomination for a [[GAA All Stars Awards|GAA All-Star]], and offering them the chance to compete against teams of high quality.<ref name="Sportslines">{{cite web|url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/gaelic-football/sportslines-129744.html|title=Sportslines|date=2006-05-07|accessdate=2009-04-29|publisher=''[[Irish Independent]]''}}</ref> The first series was specifically dedicated to male footballers and hurlers.<ref name="Handball ace Brady returns to alleviate Cavan plight"/> In June 2008, Adare Productions requested female applications for a follow-up series of ''The Underdogs''.<ref name="wrong calls">{{cite web|url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/other-sports/wrong-calls-1401982.html|title=wrong calls|date=2008-06-08|accessdate=2009-04-29|publisher=''[[Irish Independent]]''}}</ref> [[Brian Mullins]] managed the winning team which competed against the [[All-Ireland Senior Ladies' Football Championship|All-Ireland champions]] the following December.<ref name="Handball ace Brady returns to alleviate Cavan plight">{{cite web|url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/gaelic-football/handball-ace-brady-returns-to-alleviate-cavan-plight-96542.html|title=Handball ace Brady returns to alleviate Cavan plight|date=2006-05-06|accessdate=2009-04-29|publisher=''[[Irish Independent]]''}}</ref>
===''Glas Vegas'' (2007)=== ''Glas Vegas'', which was first broadcast on TG4 in August 2007, saw the introduction of a new presenter, [[Gemma Ní Chionnaith]].<ref name="Expect to find me smiling in a serene and senatorial way">{{cite web|url=http://www.independent.ie/opinion/analysis/expect-to-find-me-smiling-in--a-serene-and-senatorial-way-1061975.html|title=Expect to find me smiling in a serene and senatorial way|date=2007-08-19|accessdate=2009-04-29|publisher=''[[Irish Independent]]''}}</ref>
===''Fáilte Towers'' (2008)=== ''Fáilte Towers'' was broadcast on RTÉ One in August 2008, succeeding such shows as ''[[Cabin Fever (TV series)|Cabin Fever]]'' and ''[[Celebrity Farm]]''.<ref name="The reality is Big Brother's days are truly numbered..."/> A reality style television programme in a brand new format, it was presented by [[Aidan Power]] and [[Bazil Ashmawy]]<ref name="Presenters">[http://www.rte.ie/tv/failtetowers/presenters.html "Presenters"]. RTÉ. Accessed 29 April 2009.</ref> and the concept involved thirteen celebrities running a hotel for sixteen days and nights in order to win money for their designated charities. It was unpopular with critics but enjoyed by the general public, with the final receiving nearly a million viewers and the entire series regularly receiving between 350,000 and 450,000 viewers throughout its run.<ref name="Failte Towers: So what do the critics say about the million people who watched it?">{{cite web|url=http://www.independent.ie/entertainment/tv-radio/failte-towers--so-what-do-the--critics-say-about-the-million--people-who-watched-it-1461633.html|title=Failte Towers: So what do the critics say about the million people who watched it?|date=2008-08-23|accessdate=2009-04-29|publisher=''[[Irish Independent]]''}}</ref> The format for the show even attracted interest from overseas buyers, including investors from [[England]], but RTÉ said at the time that “no agreements [would] be reached until the current series has finished”.<ref name="Failte Towers format attracts interest from foreign buyers">{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/ireland/article4494192.ece|title=Failte Towers format attracts interest from foreign buyers|date=2008-08-10|accessdate=2008-08-11|publisher=''[[The Sunday Times]]'' | location=London | first=Jan | last=Battles}}</ref> Nevertheless, the ''[[Irish Independent]]'' named ''Fáilte Towers'' as one of the six worst television programmes of 2008, describing it as "car crash television".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.independent.ie/entertainment/tv-radio/tv-best-and-worst-of-2008-1586392.html|title=TV best and worst of 2008|date=2008-12-27|accessdate=2009-01-06|publisher=''[[Irish Independent]]''}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.adareproductions.ie/ Official website] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20081006221939/http://www.screenproducersireland.com/index.php/spi/production_companies/companies/adare_productions List of productions] at Screen Producers Ireland
[[Category:Entertainment companies of Ireland]]

{{refimprove|date=August 2018}} {{Infobox graphic novel |title = Avatar: The Last Airbender – The Lost Adventures |foreigntitle = |image = Avatar The Last Airbender The Lost Adventures cover.jpg |imagesize = 230 |caption = ''Avatar: The Last Airbender – The Lost Adventures'' cover |publisher = [[Dark Horse Comics]] |date = June 15, 2011 |issues = |series = |main_char_team = |origpublication = ''[[Avatar: The Last Airbender (comics)|Avatar: The Last Airbender]]'' |origissues = |origdate = |origlanguage = |origisbn = 9781595827487 |writers = |artists = |pencillers = |inkers = |colourists = |letterers = |editors = Samantha Robertson |creators = [[Michael Dante DiMartino]]
[[Bryan Konietzko]] |transpublisher = |transdate = |transisbn = |pages = |translator = |previssue = |nextissue = |US = }} '''''The Avatar: The Last Airbender – The Lost Adventures''''' is a graphic novel anthology published by [[Dark Horse Comics]] collecting short stories from 2005 to 2011. ''The Lost Adventures'' features twenty-six in-continuity stories set throughout the run of the [[Avatar: The Last Airbender|''Avatar: The Last Airbender'' TV series]], most of which had previously appeared in ''Nickelodeon Magazine'' or as part of DVD collections. Many of the of writers and artists worked on the original animated series.{{cite web |title=Avatar: The Last Airbender – The Lost Adventures |url=https://www.darkhorse.com/Books/18-849/Avatar-The-Last-Airbender-The-Lost-Adventures-TPB |website=Dark Horse Comics |accessdate=August 15, 2018}} ==Stories== ''The Lost Adventures'' is divided into three books—Water, Earth, and Fire—corresponding to the three seasons of the TV series. On the table below, creators marked with a † worked on the ''Avatar: The Last Airbender'' TV series, and creators marked with a ‡ worked on ''The Legend of Korra'' TV series. {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center" |- ! colspan=2|Title ! Story ! Art ! Colors ! Lettering |- ! rowspan=15 style=background:#a3c8fd|'''Book
One
—

revision.comment: Reverted edits by [[Special:Contribs/89.241.217.136|89.241.217.136]] ([[User talk:89.241.217.136|talk]]) to last version by Linguistical
revision.text:
[[File:Alison Bechdel at Politics and Prose.jpg|thumb| upright|The test is named after the American cartoonist [[Alison Bechdel]].]] The '''Bechdel test''' ({{IPAc-en|'|b|ɛ|k|d|əl}} {{respell|BEK|dəl}})<ref>{{cite web|title=Alison Bechdel Audio Name Pronunciation|url=http://www.teachingbooks.net/pronounce.cgi?aid=10597|website=TeachingBooks.net|accessdate=2017-12-30}}</ref> is a measure of the representation of women in fiction. It asks whether a work features at least two women who talk to each other about something other than a man. The requirement that the two women must be named is sometimes added.<ref name="savigny et al">{{cite book |last1=Raalte |first1=Christa van |editor1-last=Savigny |editor1-first=Heather |editor2-last=Thorsen |editor2-first=Einar |editor3-last=Jackson |editor3-first=Daniel |editor4-last=Alexander |editor4-first=Jenny |title=Media, Margins and Popular Culture |date=2015 |publisher=Springer |isbn=9781137512819 |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=Er2hCgAAQBAJ&lpg=PT32&pg=PT32 |accessdate=10 June 2018 |language=en |chapter=1. No Small-Talk in Paradise: Why Elysium Fails the Bechdel Test, and Why We Should Care}}</ref>
About half of all films meet these criteria, according to user-edited databases and the media industry press.<!-- Please refer to sources cited below, the lead paragraph cites sources only for quotations --> The test is used as an indicator for the active presence of women in films and other fiction, and to call attention to [[gender inequality in fiction]].
Also known as the '''Bechdel–Wallace test''',<ref>{{cite news|title=Alison Bechdel Would Like You to Call It the "Bechdel–Wallace Test," ThankYouVeryMuch|url=http://www.themarysue.com/bechdel-wallace-test-please-alison-bechdel/|accessdate=26 August 2015|date=25 August 2015}}</ref> it is named after the American cartoonist [[Alison Bechdel]], in whose comic strip, ''[[Dykes to Watch Out For]]'', the test first appeared, in 1985. Bechdel credited the idea to a friend, Liz Wallace, and to the writings of [[Virginia Woolf]]. After the test became more widely discussed in the 2000s, a number of variants and tests inspired by it have been introduced.
==History==
===Gender portrayal in popular fiction=== [[File:Female and male characters in film.png|thumb|upright=1.75|Female and male characters in film, according to four studies]] In her 1929 essay ''[[A Room of One's Own]]'', [[Virginia Woolf]] observed about the literature of her time what the Bechdel test would later highlight in more recent fiction:<ref>{{cite news|title=Bechdel-Test: Frauen spielen keine Rolle|url=http://kurier.at/kultur/4506969-bechdel-test-frauen-spielen-keine-rolle.php|accessdate=19 August 2012|newspaper=[[Kurier]]|date=8 August 2012}}</ref>
{{quote|All these relationships between women, I thought, rapidly recalling the splendid gallery of fictitious women, are too simple. ... And I tried to remember any case in the course of my reading where two women are represented as friends. ... They are now and then mothers and daughters. But almost without exception they are shown in their relation to men. It was strange to think that all the great women of fiction were, until [[Jane Austen]]'s day, not only seen by the other sex, but seen only in relation to the other sex. And how small a part of a woman's life is that ...<ref>{{cite web|last=Woolf|first=Virginia|title=A Room of One's Own: Chapter 5|url=http://ebooks.adelaide.edu.au/w/woolf/virginia/w91r/complete.html|work=[[University of Adelaide#North Terrace|The University of Adelaide Library]]|publisher=[[University of Adelaide Press]]|accessdate=24 December 2012|authorlink=Virginia Woolf|editor=Thomas, Stephen}}</ref>}}
In film, a study of gender portrayals in 855 of the most financially successful U.S. films from 1950 to 2006 showed that there were, on average, two male characters for each female character, a ratio that remained stable over time. Female characters were portrayed as being involved in sex twice as often as male characters, and their proportion of scenes with explicit sexual content increased over time. Violence increased over time in male and female characters alike.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Bleakley | first1 = A. | last2 = Jamieson | first2 = P. E. | last3 = Romer | first3 = D. | doi = 10.1016/j.jadohealth.2012.02.006 | title = Trends of Sexual and Violent Content by Gender in Top-Grossing U.S. Films, 1950–2006 | journal = Journal of Adolescent Health | volume = 51 | issue = 1 | pages = 73–79 | year = 2012 | pmid = 22727080| pmc = }}</ref>
According to a 2014 study by the [[Geena Davis Institute on Gender in Media]], in 120 films made worldwide from 2010 to 2013, only 31% of named characters were female, and 23% of the films had a female protagonist or co-protagonist. 7% of directors were women.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Sakoui|first1=Anousha|last2=Magnusson|first2=Niklas|title='Hunger Games' success masks stubborn gender gap in Hollywood|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/sns-wp-blm-news-bc-film-women22-20140922-story.html|accessdate=22 September 2014|work=[[Chicago Tribune]]|date=22 September 2014}} With reference to: {{cite web|last1=Smith|first1=Stacy L.|last2=Pieper|first2=Katherine|title=Gender Bias Without Borders: An Investigation of Female Characters in Popular Films Across 11 Countries|url=http://seejane.org/symposiums-on-gender-in-media/gender-bias-without-borders/|website=See Jane|accessdate=16 April 2016|language=en-US}}</ref> Another study looking at the 700 top‐grossing films from 2007 to 2014 found that only 30% of the speaking characters were female.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Smith|first1=Stacy L.|last2=Choueiti|first2=Marc|last3=Pieper|first3=Katherine|last4=Gillig|first4=Traci|last5=Lee|first5=Carmen|last6=Dylan|first6=DeLuca|title=Inequality in 700 Popular Films: Examining Portrayals of Gender, Race, & LGBT Status from 2007 to 2014|url=http://annenberg.usc.edu/pages/~/media/MDSCI/Inequality%20in%20700%20Popular%20Films%208215%20Final%20for%20Posting.ashx|publisher=USC Annenberg School for Communication and Journalism|accessdate=6 August 2015}}</ref> In a 2016 analysis of [[screenplay]]s of 2,005 commercially successful films, Hanah Anderson and Matt Daniels found that in 82% of the films, men had two of the top three speaking roles, while a woman had the most dialogue in only 22% of films.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Swanson|first1=Ana|title=The problem with almost all movies|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/wonk/wp/2016/04/12/the-problem-with-almost-all-movies/|work=The Washington Post|date=12 April 2016|language=en-US}} With reference to: {{cite web|last1=Anderson|first1=Hanah|last2=Daniels|first2=Matt|title=The Largest Analysis of Film Dialogue by Gender, Ever|url=http://polygraph.cool/films/|website=Polygraph|language=en-US}}</ref>
===The Bechdel test=== [[File:Dykes to Watch Out For (Bechdel test origin).jpg|400px|thumb|A character in ''[[Dykes to Watch Out For]]'' explains the rules that later came to be known as the Bechdel test (1985)]] The rules now known as the Bechdel test first appeared in 1985 in Alison Bechdel's comic strip ''[[Dykes To Watch Out For]]''. In a strip titled "The Rule", two women, who resemble the future characters Mo and Ginger,<ref name="Martindale"/> discuss seeing a film and one woman explains that she only goes to a movie if it satisfies the following requirements: # The movie has to have at least two women in it, # who talk to each other, # about something besides a man.<ref>Bechdel, Allison. Dykes to Watch Out For. Firebrand Books (October 1, 1986). {{ISBN|978-0932379177}}</ref><ref>[https://www.flickr.com/photos/zizyphus/34585797/in/photostream/ "The Rule" comic page posted on Alison Bechdel's online photostream]</ref><ref name=AB>{{cite web|url=https://alisonbechdel.blogspot.com/2005/08/rule.html|title=The Rule|author=Alison Bechdel|date=August 16, 2005|publisher=DTWOF: The Blog|accessdate=16 September 2018}}</ref>
The other woman acknowledges that the idea is pretty strict, but good. Not finding any films that meet their requirements, they go home together.<ref name="Martindale">{{cite book|last1=Martindale|first1=Kathleen|title=Un/Popular Culture: Lesbian Writing After the Sex Wars|date=1997|publisher=State Univ. of New York Press|location=Albany, NY|isbn=0791432890|page=69|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UO8kUNqHhgQC&lpg=PA69&pg=PA69}}</ref>
The test has also been referred to as the "Bechdel–Wallace test"<ref name="sparqling" /> (which Bechdel herself prefers),<ref>On the [[Fresh Air]] program on NPR on August 17, 2015, in response to a question from host Terry Gross, Bechdel said she would prefer the test be referred to as the Bechdel–Wallace Test.</ref> the "Bechdel rule",<ref name="ok" /> "Bechdel's law",<ref name="antipope" /> or the "Mo Movie Measure".<ref name=AB/> Bechdel credited the idea for the test to a friend and [[karate]] training partner, Liz Wallace, whose name appears in the [[marquee (sign)|marquee]] of the strip.<ref name=NPR>[https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=94202522 NPR] [[Neda Ulaby|Ulaby, Neda]] "The 'Bechdel Rule,' Defining Pop-Culture Character". September 2, 2008.</ref><ref name="New Yorker 11 April 2011">{{Cite journal |last1=Friend |first1=Tad |authorlink=Tad Friend |date=11 April 2011 |title=Funny Like a Guy: Anna Faris and Hollywood's woman problem |journal=The New Yorker |publisher=Condé Nast |page=55 |url=http://www.newyorker.com/reporting/2011/04/11/110411fa_fact_friend |accessdate=2011-09-17}}</ref> She later wrote that she was pretty certain that Wallace was inspired by Virginia Woolf's essay ''[[A Room of One's Own]]''.<ref name=T>[http://dykestowatchoutfor.com/testy Bechdel, Allison. "Testy". Alison Bechdel blog. Posted November 8, 2013].</ref>
Originally meant as "a little lesbian joke in an alternative feminist newspaper", according to Bechdel,<ref name="San Diego City Beat 23 July 2014">{{cite news|last1=Morlan|first1=Kinsee|title=Comic-Con vs. the Bechdel Test|url=http://www.sdcitybeat.com/sandiego/article-13243-comic-con-vs-the-bechdel-test.html|accessdate=15 August 2014|work=[[San Diego City Beat]]|date=23 July 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150316161800/http://www.sdcitybeat.com/sandiego/article-13243-comic-con-vs-the-bechdel-test.html|archivedate=16 March 2015|df=}}</ref> the test moved into mainstream criticism in the 2010s and has been described as "the standard by which feminist critics judge television, movies, books, and other media".<ref>{{cite book|last=Steiger|first=Kay|editor-first=James|editor-last=Lowder|title=Triumph of The Walking Dead|chapter=No Clean Slate: Unshakeable race and gender politics in ''The Walking Dead''|year=2011|publisher=[[BenBella Books]]|isbn=9781936661138|page=104|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Lz3fp1fVw90C&pg=PA104&lpg=PA104|accessdate=2014-04-20}}</ref> In 2013, an Internet newspaper described it as "almost a household phrase, common shorthand to capture whether a film is woman-friendly".<ref name="The Daily Dot 18 August 2013">{{cite news|last=Romano|first=Aja|title=The Mako Mori Test: 'Pacific Rim' inspires a Bechdel Test alternative|url=http://www.dailydot.com/fandom/mako-mori-test-bechdel-pacific-rim/|accessdate=15 September 2013|newspaper=[[The Daily Dot]]|date=18 August 2013}}</ref> The failure of major Hollywood productions such as ''[[Pacific Rim (film)|Pacific Rim]]'' (2013) to pass the test was addressed in depth in the media.<ref name="Metro 18 July 2013">{{cite news|last=McGuinness|first=Ross|title=The Bechdel test and why Hollywood is a man's, man's, man's world|url=http://metro.co.uk/2013/07/18/movie-lovers-hit-back-at-hollywood-misogyny-with-the-bechdel-test-3886103/|accessdate=15 September 2013|newspaper=[[Metro (British newspaper)|Metro]]|date=18 July 2013}}</ref>
According to [[Neda Ulaby]], the test resonates because "it articulates something often missing in popular culture: not the number of women we see on screen, but the depth of their stories, and the range of their concerns."<ref name=NPR/> Dean Spade and Craig Willse described the test as a "commentary on how media representations enforce harmful [[gender norm]]s" by depicting women's relationships to men more than any other relationships, and women's lives as important only insofar as they relate to men.<ref>{{cite book|first1=Dean |last1=Spade|first2=Craig |last2=Willse|editor-last=Hawkesworth|editor-first=Mary|title=The Oxford Handbook of Feminist Theory|date=2016|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9780199328581|page=556}}</ref>
Several variants of the test have been proposed—for example, that the two women must be named characters,<ref name="EW 6 August 2010"/> or that there must be at least a total of 60 seconds of conversation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.feministfrequency.com/2012/02/the-2012-oscars-and-the-bechdel-test/ |title=The Oscars and the Bechdel Test |publisher=Feminist Frequency |date=February 15, 2012 |accessdate=2013-11-08}}</ref> The test has also attracted academic interest from a computational analysis approach.<ref>[http://aclweb.org/anthology/N/N15/N15-1084.pdf Bechdel Test academic paper.]</ref> In June 2018, the Bechdel test was added to the [[Oxford English Dictionary]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Suh |first1=Haley |title=Words To Know By Now: Binge-Watching, Bechdel Test Added To Oxford English Dictionary |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/haleysuh/2018/06/15/words-to-know-by-now-binge-watching-bechdel-test-added-to-oxford-english-dictionary |accessdate=20 June 2018 |work=Forbes |date=15 June 2018 |language=en}}</ref>
===Use in the film industry=== In 2013, four Swedish cinemas and the Scandinavian cable television channel [[Viasat Film]] incorporated the Bechdel test into some of their ratings, a move supported by the [[Swedish Film Institute]].<ref name="G">{{cite news|agency=Associated Press |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/nov/06/swedish-cinemas-bechdel-test-films-gender-bias |title=Swedish cinemas take aim at gender bias with Bechdel test rating |work=The Guardian |date=November 6, 2013 |accessdate=2013-11-08}}</ref>
In 2014, the European cinema fund [[Eurimages]] incorporated the Bechdel test into its submission mechanism as part of an effort to collect information about gender equality in its projects. It requires "a Bechdel analysis of the script to be supplied by the script readers".<ref>{{cite web|title=Gender equality within Eurimages: current situation and scope for evolution|url=http://www.ewawomen.com/en/eurimages-news.html|website=European Women's Audiovisual Network|accessdate=6 August 2015}}</ref>
In 2018, [[screenwriting software]] developers began incorporating functions that allow writers to analyze their scripts for gender representation. Software with such functions includes [[Highland 2]], [[WriterDuet]] and the forthcoming [[Final Draft (software)|Final Draft]] 11.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Ryzik |first1=Melena |title=Is your script gender-balanced? The new test helping filmmakers get it right |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/films/features/film-scripts-gender-balanced-software-bechdel-test-christina-hodson-oscars-a8361336.html |accessdate=20 June 2018 |work=The Independent |date=21 May 2018}}</ref>
==Application==
In addition to films, the Bechdel test has been applied to other media such as video games<ref>{{cite book|last1=Gray|first1=Kishonna|title=Race, Gender, and Deviance in Xbox Live: Theoretical Perspectives from the Virtual Margins|date=2014|publisher=Routledge|isbn=1317521803|page=28|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Xh-gBAAAQBAJ&lpg=PA28&pg=PA28}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last=Anthropy |first=Anna |title=Rise of the videogame zinesters: How freaks, normals, amateurs, artists, dreamers, dropouts, queers, housewives, and people like you are taking back an art form |year=2012 |publisher=Seven Stories Press |isbn=9781609803735 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nc3GRXqgPZ8C&lpg=PT7 |edition=Seven Stories Press 1st |accessdate=2014-04-20 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Agnello |first=Anthony John |title=Something other than a man: 15 games that pass the Bechdel Test |url=http://gameological.com/2012/07/something-other-than-a-man-15-games-that-pass-the-bechdel-test/ |accessdate=26 July 2012 |work=Gameological |date=July 2012 }}</ref> and comics.<ref name="MTV Geek! 22 February 2012">{{cite news |last=Zalben |first=Alex |title=''Witchblade''/''Red Sonja #1'' Passes The Bechdel Test |url=http://geek-news.mtv.com/2012/02/22/witchbladered-sonja-1-passes-the-bechdel-test-advance-review/ |accessdate=26 July 2012 |newspaper=[[MTV Geek!]] |date=22 February 2012 }}</ref> In theater, British actor Beth Watson launched a "Bechdel Theatre" campaign in 2015 that aims to highlight test-passing plays.<ref>{{Cite web|author=Jo Caird|title = Does your show pass the Bechdel test? {{!}} Opinion |url = https://www.thestage.co.uk/opinion/2015/does-your-show-pass-the-bechdel-test/|website = The Stage|date=14 October 2015|access-date = 2016-02-05|language = en-US}}</ref>
===Pass and fail proportions=== The website ''bechdeltest.com'' is a user-edited database of some 6,500 films classified by whether they pass the test, with the added requirement that the women must be ''named'' characters. {{as of|April 2015}}, it listed 58% of these films as passing all three of the test's requirements, 10% as failing one, 22% as failing two, and 10% as failing all three.<ref>{{cite web |title=Statistics |url=http://bechdeltest.com/statistics/ |work=bechdeltest.com |accessdate=13 November 2013 }}</ref>
According to [[Mark Harris (journalist)|Mark Harris]] of ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'', if passing the test were mandatory, it would have jeopardized half of the 2009 [[Academy Award for Best Picture]] nominees.<ref name="EW 6 August 2010">{{cite news |last=Harris |first=Mark |title=I Am Woman. Hear Me... Please! |url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,20408121,00.html |accessdate=26 July 2012 |newspaper=[[Entertainment Weekly]] |date=6 August 2010 }}</ref> The news website ''[[Vocativ]]'', when subjecting the top-grossing films of 2013 to the Bechdel test, concluded that roughly half of them passed (although some dubiously) and the other half failed.<ref name="Vocativ 2014">{{cite news |last1= Sharma |first1= Versha |last2= Sender |first2= Hanna |title= Hollywood Movies With Strong Female Roles Make More Money |url= http://www.vocativ.com/culture/celebrity/hollywood-movies-strong-female-roles-make-money/ |accessdate= 2 January 2014 |newspaper= Vocativ |date= 2 January 2014 }}</ref>
Writer [[Charles Stross]] noted that about half of the films that ''do'' pass the test only do so because the women talk about marriage or babies.<ref name="Power 2009">{{cite book |last=Power |first=Nina |title=One-dimensional woman |year=2009 |publisher=Zero Books |isbn=1846942411 |pages=39 et seq. |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=u3gDWJEJblEC&pg=PA39 |accessdate=2014-04-20 }}</ref> Works that fail the test include some that are mainly about or aimed at women, or which do feature prominent female characters. The television series ''[[Sex and the City]]'' highlights its own failure to pass the test by having one of the four female main characters ask: "How does it happen that four such smart women have nothing to talk about but boyfriends? It's like seventh grade with bank accounts!"<ref name=NPR/>
===Financial aspects=== ''Vocativ''{{'}}s authors also found that the films from 2013 that passed the test earned a total of $4.22 billion in the United States, while those that failed earned $2.66 billion in total, leading them to conclude that a way for Hollywood to make more money might be to "put more women onscreen."<ref name="Vocativ 2014"/> A 2014 study by [[FiveThirtyEight]] based on data from about 1,615 films released from 1990 to 2013 concluded that the [[median]] budget of films that passed the test was 35% lower than that of the others. It found that the films that passed the test had about a 37 percent higher [[return on investment]] (ROI) in the United States, and the same ROI internationally, compared to films that did not pass the test.<ref name="538 2014">{{cite news |newspaper= FiveThirtyEight |first= Walt |last= Hickey |title= The Dollar-And-Cents Case Against Hollywood's Exclusion of Women |date= 1 April 2014 |url= http://fivethirtyeight.com/features/the-dollar-and-cents-case-against-hollywoods-exclusion-of-women/ }}</ref>
===Explanations=== Explanations that have been offered as to why many films fail the Bechdel test include the relative lack of gender [[diversity (politics)|diversity]] among scriptwriters<ref name=NPR/> and other movie professionals, also called the "[[celluloid ceiling]]": In 2012, only one in six of the directors, writers, and producers behind the 100 most commercially successful movies in the United States was a woman.<ref name="Metro 18 July 2013" />
Writing in ''[[National Review]]'' in 2017, film critic [[Kyle Smith]] suggested that the reason for the Bechdel test results was that "Hollywood movies are about people on the extremes of society — cops, criminals, superheroes — [which] tend to be men", and that such films were more often created by men because "women's movie ideas", mostly about relationships according to Smith, "aren't commercial enough for Hollywood studios".<ref name="Smith 2017">{{cite news|last1=Smith|first1=Kyle|title=If You Like Art, Don’t Take the Bechdel Test|url=http://www.nationalreview.com/article/449340/bechdel-test-feminist-litmus-test-movies-useless-political-correctness|accessdate=18 July 2017|work=National Review|date=10 July 2017|language=en}}</ref> He considered the Bechdel test just as meaningless as a test asking whether a film contained [[cowboy]]s.<ref name="Smith 2017" /> Smith's article provoked vigorous criticism.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Gettell|first1=Oliver|title=Conservative Film Critic Slammed for Bechdel Test Takedown|url=http://ew.com/movies/2017/07/10/kyle-smith-slammed-bechdel-test-takedown/|accessdate=18 July 2017|work=[[EW.com]]|date=11 July 2017}}</ref> Alessandra Maldonado and Liz Bourke wrote that Smith was wrong to contend that female authors do not write books that generate "big movie ideas", citing [[J. K. Rowling]], [[Margaret Atwood]] and [[Nnedi Okorafor]] among others as counter-examples.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Maldonado|first1=Alessandra|title="National Review" mansplainer tries to take down Bechdel Test with "cowboy test"|url=http://www.salon.com/2017/07/11/national-review-bechdel-test/|accessdate=18 July 2017|work=Salon|date=11 July 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Bourke|first1=Liz|title=Sleeps With Monsters: Stop Erasing Women’s Presence in SFF|url=http://www.tor.com/2017/07/18/sleeps-with-monsters-stop-erasing-womens-presence-in-sff/|accessdate=18 July 2017|work=Tor.com|date=18 July 2017}}</ref>
== Limitations == The Bechdel test only indicates whether women are present in a work of fiction to a certain degree. A work may pass the test and still contain sexist content, and a work with prominent female characters may fail the test.<ref name="ok">{{cite news|url=http://www.oudaily.com/l_and_a/arts_and_entertainment/column-bechdel-rule-still-applies-to-portrayal-of-women-in/article_d3dc6a7d-8fcb-589c-885a-649fe33db5e1.html |first=Sarah |last=Wilson |date=28 June 2012 |publisher=The Oklahoma Daily |title=Bechdel Rule still applies to portrayal of women in films}}</ref> A work may fail the test for reasons unrelated to gender bias, such as because its setting works against the inclusion of women (e.g., [[Umberto Eco]]'s ''[[The Name of the Rose (film)|The Name of the Rose]]'', set in a medieval monastery).<ref name="antipope">{{cite web|last=Stross|first=Charles|title=Bechdel's Law|url=http://www.antipope.org/charlie/blog-static/2008/07/bechdels_law.html|work=Charlie's Diary|date=28 July 2008|authorlink=Charles Stross|accessdate=26 July 2012}}</ref> What counts as a character or as a conversation is not defined (e.g., the [[Sir Mix-a-Lot]] song "[[Baby Got Back]]" has been described as passing the Bechdel test, because it begins with audio of a [[valley girl]] saying "oh my god, Becky, look at her butt")<ref name=LifehackerDouglas>[https://lifehacker.com/the-bechdel-test-and-other-media-representation-tests-1819324045 The Bechdel Test, and Other Media Representation Tests, Explained], by Nick Douglas, at ''[[Lifehacker]]''; published October 10, 2017; retrieved April 17, 2018</ref><ref name=JezebelSimulator>[https://jezebel.com/this-bechdel-test-simulator-shows-how-easy-it-is-to-pre-1753250185 This Bechdel Test Simulator Shows How Easy It Is to Predict Who Makes Sexist Movies (Men)], by Kara Brown, at ''[[Jezebel (website)|Jezebel]]''; published January 15, 2016; retrieved April 17, 2018</ref> and works with very few of either will often fail the test automatically.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Gomez Maureira |first1=M.A.|last2=Rombout|first2=L.E.|editor1-last=Chorianopoulos|editor1-first=Konstantinos|title=Entertainment Computing - ICEC 2015: 14th International Conference, ICEC 2015, Trondheim, Norway, September 29 - October 2, 2015, Proceedings|date=2015|publisher=Springer|isbn=9783319245898|page=546|chapter=Sonifying Gender Representation in Film}}</ref>
In an attempt at a [[Quantitative research|quantitative]] analysis of works as to whether they pass the test, at least one researcher, Faith Lawrence, noted that the results depend on how rigorously the test is applied. One of the questions arising from its application is whether a reference to a man at any point within a conversation that also covers other topics invalidates the entire exchange. If not, the question remains how one defines the start and end of a conversation.<ref name="sparqling">{{cite web|last=Lawrence|first=Faith|title=SPARQLing Conversation: Automating The Bechdel–Wallace Test|url=http://nht.ecs.soton.ac.uk/2011/papers/12-flawrence.pdf|date=June 2011|work=Paper presented at the Narrative and Hypertext Workshop, Hypertext 2011|accessdate=26 July 2012}}</ref>
==Criticism== In response to its increasing ubiquity in film criticism, the Bechdel test has been criticized for not taking into account the quality of the works it tests (bad films may pass it, and good ones fail), or as a "nefarious plot to make all movies conform to [[feminist]] dogma".<ref name="Zeisler 2016">{{cite book|title=We Were Feminists Once: From Riot Grrrl to CoverGirl¨, the Buying and Selling of a Political Movement|date=2016|publisher=PublicAffairs|isbn=9781610395892|pages=55–57}}</ref> According to [[Andi Zeisler]], this criticism indicates the problem that the test's utility "has been elevated way beyond the original intention. Where Bechdel and Wallace expressed it as simply a way to point out the rote, unthinkingly normative plotlines of mainstream film, these days passing it has somehow become synonymous with 'being feminist'. It was never meant to be a measure of feminism, but rather a cultural barometer." Zeisler noted that the false assumption that a work that passes the test is "feminist" might lead to creators "gaming the system" by adding just enough women characters and dialogue to pass the test,<ref name="Zeisler 2016" /> while continuing to deny women substantial representation outside of formulaic plots.
Similarly, the ''[[The Daily Telegraph|Telegraph]]'' film critic [[Robbie Collin]] disapproved of the test as prizing "box-ticking and stat-hoarding over analysis and appreciation", and suggested that the underlying problem of the lack of well-drawn female characters in film ought to be a topic of discourse, rather than individual films failing or passing the Bechdel test.<ref>{{cite news|last=Collin|first=Robbie|title=Bechdel test is damaging to the way we think about film|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/film/10450463/Bechdel-test-is-damaging-to-the-way-we-think-about-film.html|accessdate=15 November 2013|newspaper=The Telegraph|date=15 November 2013}}</ref> ''FiveThirtyEight''{{'}}s writer Walt Hickey noted that the test does not measure whether any one film is a model of gender equality, and that passing it does not ensure the quality of writing, significance or depth of female roles—but, he wrote, "it's the best test on gender equity in film we have—and, perhaps more important ..., the only test we have data on".<ref name="538 2014" />
[[Nina Power]] wrote that the test raises the questions of whether fiction has a duty to represent women (rather than to pursue whatever the creator's own agenda might be) and to be "realistic" in the representation of women. She also wrote that it remained to be determined how often real life passes the Bechdel test, and what the influence of fiction on that might be.<ref name="Power 2009" />
==Derived tests==<!-- In alphabetical order --> [[File:Rinko Kikuchi Berlin 2015.jpg|thumb|upright|The character Mako Mori (played by [[Rinko Kikuchi]], pictured) inspired an alternative test for measuring female presence in fiction.]] The Bechdel test has inspired others, notably feminist and antiracist critics and fans, to formulate criteria for evaluating works of fiction, in part because of the Bechdel test's limitations.<ref name="Zeisler 2016" /> In interviews conducted by [[FiveThirtyEight]], women in the film and television industry proposed many other tests that included more women, better stories, women behind the scenes, and more diversity.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/next-bechdel/|title=Creating The Next Bechdel Test|publisher=FiveThirtyEight|accessdate=December 22, 2017}}</ref>
===Tests about gender and fiction=== The "Mako Mori test", formulated by [[Tumblr]] user "Chaila"<ref>{{cite news|last1=Wilson|first1=Lena|title=Pacific Rim Inspired the "Mako Mori Test." Uprising Gives the Character a Far Less Inspiring Arc.|url=https://slate.com/culture/2018/03/pacific-rim-uprisings-disappointing-treatment-of-mako-mori-spoilers.html|accessdate=8 April 2018|work=Slate Magazine|language=en}}</ref> and named after the only significant female character of the 2013 film ''[[Pacific Rim (film)|Pacific Rim]]'', asks whether a female character has a [[narrative arc]] that is not about supporting a man's story.<ref name="Zeisler 2016" /> (In the sequel [[Pacific Rim Uprising]], Mori failed the test by dying a few minutes into the film to further her brother's story.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Corde |first1=Phoebe |title=Does 'Pacific Rim: Uprising' Pass The Mako Mori Test? |url=https://www.theodysseyonline.com/pacific-rim-uprising-pass-mako-mori-test |accessdate=22 October 2018 |work=The Odyssey Online |date=2 April 2018 |language=en-us}}</ref>) Comic book writer [[Kelly Sue DeConnick]] proposed a "sexy lamp test": "If you can replace your female character with a sexy lamp and the story still basically works, maybe you need another draft."<ref>{{cite web|title=Kelly Sue Deconnick on the Evolution of Carol Danvers to Captain Marvel [Interview] |url=http://comicsalliance.com/kelly-sue-deconnick-captain-marvel/ |first=Laura |last=Hudson |date=March 19, 2012 |work=[[Comics Alliance]] |accessdate=April 27, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150502093329/http://comicsalliance.com/kelly-sue-deconnick-captain-marvel/ |archivedate=May 2, 2015 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://sequart.org/magazine/34150/the-bechdel-test-and-a-sexy-lamp-detecting-gender-bias-and-stereotypes-in-mainstream-comics/|title=The Bechdel Test and a Sexy Lamp|first=Forrest|last=Helvie|date=November 21, 2013|work=[[Sequart Organization]]|accessdate=April 27, 2015}}</ref>
The "Sphinx test" by the Sphinx theater company of London asks about the interaction of women with other characters, as well as how prominently women characters feature in the action, how proactive rather than reactive they are, and whether they are portrayed stereotypically. It was conceived to "encourage theatremakers to think about how to write more and better roles for women", in reaction to research indicating that only 37% of theater roles were written for women {{as of|2014|lc=y}}.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Snow|first1=Georgia|title=Theatre gets its own Bechdel Test|url=https://www.thestage.co.uk/news/2015/theatre-gets-its-own-bechdel-test/|accessdate=6 December 2015|work=[[The Stage]]|date=30 November 2015}}</ref>
===Tests about characteristics other than gender===
====Sexuality==== The "[[Vito Russo]] test" created by the [[LGBT]] organization [[GLAAD]] tests for the representation of LGBT characters in films. It asks: Does the film contain a character that is identifiably LGBT, and is not solely or predominantly defined by their sexual orientation or gender identity, as well as tied into the plot in such a way that their removal would have a significant effect?<ref>{{cite web |title=GLAAD introduces 'Studio Responsibility Index', report on LGBT images in films released by 'Big Six' studios |url=http://www.glaad.org/releases/glaad-introduces-studio-responsibility-index-report-lgbt-images-films-released-big-six |date=August 20, 2013 |publisher=[[GLAAD]] |accessdate=August 24, 2013 }}</ref><ref name="The Atlantic 21 August 2013">{{cite news|last=John|first=Arit|title=Beyond the Bechdel Test: Two (New) Ways of Looking at Movies|url=http://www.theatlanticwire.com/entertainment/2013/08/beyond-bechdel-test-two-new-ways-looking-movies/68563/|accessdate=15 September 2013|newspaper=The Atlantic|date=21 August 2013}}</ref>
====People of color==== A test proposed by TV critic Eric Deggans asks whether a film that is not about race has at least two non-white characters in the main cast,<ref name="Zeisler 2016" /> and similarly, writer Nikesh Shukla proposed a test about whether there are two main characters who are [[people of color]], who talk to each other without mentioning their race.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Shukla|first1=Nikesh|title=After the Bechdel Test, I propose the Shukla Test for race in film|url=http://www.newstatesman.com/2013/10/after-bechdel-test-i-propose-shukla-test-race-film|accessdate=22 November 2016|work=[[New Statesman]]|date=18 October 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Dawn|first1=Randee|title=Gender and race issues are slowly fading as more filmmakers consider three key tests|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/envelope/la-en-mn-1117-film-tests-20161011-snap-20161109-story.html|accessdate=22 November 2016|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=17 November 2016}}</ref>
The ''[[New York Times]]'' film critic [[Manohla Dargis]] suggested in January 2016 the "DuVernay test", (named for director [[Ava DuVernay]]) asking whether "African-Americans and other minorities have fully realized lives rather than serve as scenery in white stories."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Dargis|first1=Manohla|title=Sundance Fights Tide With Films Like ‘The Birth of a Nation’|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/01/30/movies/sundance-fights-tide-with-films-like-the-birth-of-a-nation.html|accessdate=4 February 2018|work=The New York Times|date=29 January 2016}}</ref> It aims to point out the lack of people of color in [[Hollywood]] [[movie]]s, through a measure of their importance to a particular movie or the lack of a gratuitous link to white actors.<ref name="2016-02-01_TC">{{cite web|url=https://www.thecut.com/2016/02/could-this-be-the-bechdel-test-for-race.html|title=Could This Be the Bechdel Test for Race|accessdate=February 4, 2018|last=Evans|first=Dayna|date=February 1, 2016|work=The Cut}}</ref>
Nadia Latif and Leila Latif of ''[[The Guardian]]'' have suggested a series of five questions: * Are there two named characters of color? * Do they have dialogue? * Are they not romantically involved with one another? * Do they have any dialogue that isn't comforting or supporting a white character? * Is one of them definitely not [[Magical Negro|magic]]?<ref name="2016-01-19_NL-LL">{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/jan/18/hollywoods-race-problem-film-industry-actors-of-colour|title=How to fix Hollywood's race problem|accessdate=June 20, 2017|last1=Latif|last2=Latif|first1=Nadia|first2=Leila|date=January 18, 2016|work=The Guardian}}</ref>
A simplified version by Nikesh Shukla, already proposed in 2013, asks if "two ethnic minorities talk to each other for more than five minutes about something other than race."<ref>{{cite news|last=Shukla|first=Nikesh|title=After the Bechdel Test, I propose the Shukla Test for race in film|url=http://www.newstatesman.com/2013/10/after-bechdel-test-i-propose-shukla-test-race-film|accessdate=November 22, 2016|work=[[New Statesman]]|date=October 18, 2013}}</ref>
===Tests about nonfiction=== The Bechdel test has also inspired gender-related tests for nonfiction. Laurie Voss, [[Chief technology officer|CTO]] of [[npm (software)|npm]], proposed a Bechdel test for software. [[Source code]] passes this test if it contains a function written by a woman developer which calls a function written by a different woman developer.<ref>{{Cite tweet |user=seldo |author=Laurie Voss |number=571453200093437952 |date=27 Feb 2015 |title=Does your project pass the Bechdel test? To pass, a function written by a woman dev must call a function written by another woman dev.}}</ref> Press notice was attracted<ref>{{Citation |title=There's Now A Bechdel Test For The Tech World |url=http://thinkprogress.org/culture/2015/03/19/3635965/tech-version-bechdel-test-often-code-written-women/ |first=Lauren C. |last=Williams |date=March 19, 2015 |publisher=[[ThinkProgress]]}}</ref><ref>{{Citation |title=A Bechdel Test for Tech? |url=https://insights.dice.com/2015/03/24/a-bechdel-test-for-tech/ |first=Nick |last=Kolakowski |date=Mar 24, 2015 |publisher=[[Dice.com]]}}</ref> after the U.S. government agency [[18F]] analyzed their own software according to this metric.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://18f.gsa.gov/2015/03/17/does-18f-pass-the-bechdel-test-for-tech/ |title=Does 18F Pass the Bechdel Test for Tech? |date=March 17, 2015 |author1=Elaine Kamlley |author2=Melody Kramer}}</ref>
The Bechdel test also inspired the [[Finkbeiner test]], a checklist to help journalists to avoid gender bias in articles about [[women in science]].<ref name="CJR 22 March 2013">{{cite news |last=Brainard |first=Curtis |title='The Finkbeiner Test' Seven rules to avoid gratuitous gender profiles of female scientists |url=http://www.cjr.org/the_observatory/finkbeiner_test_gender_gap_fem.php?page=all |accessdate=31 March 2013 |newspaper=[[Columbia Journalism Review]] |date=22 March 2013 }}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== <!--Ought to be a source for article content, rather than an external link: *''[http://www.upworthy.com/little-boys-learn-a-lot-from-watching-star-wars-and-it-isnt-all-good Little Boys Learn A Lot From Watching 'Star Wars,' And It Isn't All Good]'' Colin Stokes heavily referenced the Bechdel test in his Tedx talk on female roles in film. --> *''[http://bechdeltest.com/ Bechdeltest.com]'', user-edited film database *''[http://women-in-film.silk.co/ Women in Film]'', analysis tool for data from bechdeltest.com *''[http://bechdeltestingcomics.tumblr.com/ Bechdel Testing Comics]'' blog *''[http://bechdelgamer.wordpress.com/ Bechdel Gamer]'' blog {{Women in Media}}
[[Category:Feminism and the arts]] [[Category:Sexism]] [[Category:Tests]] [[Category:Media bias]] [[Category:Concepts in film theory]] [[Category:Women in film]]

A '''beer and pretzels game''' is any of a class of [[tabletop game]]s that are light on rules and strategy, feature a high amount of randomness and a light theme.<ref name=eurogames>{{cite book |last=Woods |first=Stewart |title=Eurogames: The Design, Culture and Play of Modern European Board Games |publisher=McFarland |date=August 16, 2012 |page=221 |isbn=978-0786467976}}</ref> This is in direct contrast to [[Eurogame|Eurogames]], which involve complex rules and emphasize strategy over randomness. The term was originally coined to describe relatively simple [[Wargaming|wargames]] that did not require extraordinary focus to play. The name was then adopted by [[gamer|gamers]] to mean casual, short and easy to play games in general. Examples of beer and pretzels games include ''[[Bohnanza]]'', ''[[Wizwar]]'' and ''Pit''.<ref name=tabletop>{{cite book |last=Costikyan |first=Greg |editor-last=Davidson |editor-first=Drew |title=Tabletop: Analog Game Design |publisher=lulu.com |date=August 12, 2011 |pages=179–185 |chapter=Boardgame Aesthetics |isbn=978-1257870608}}</ref>
== Characteristics ==
Beer and pretzels games vary greatly in [[wikt:theme|theme]] and [[gameplay]], but have a set of common characteristics. Rules are simple and generally explainable in just a few minutes, turns pass quickly and humor is common. Randomness, either in the form of cards of dice is essential. Fortunes may revert quickly and the game often ends suddenly and unexpectedly. Scoring requires very simple calculations.
From a design stand-point, beer and pretzels games are non-trivial to create. They need to have enough depth to encourage repeat play without a stiff learning curve, and need to be enjoyable in quick sessions.<ref name=tabletop />
== References == {{reflist}}

{{other uses|Blackbird (disambiguation)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2012}} {{Use British English|date=May 2012}} {{Infobox play |name = Blackbird |image = Blackbird (play).jpg |image_size = 150px |caption = Script cover |writer = [[David Harrower]] |characters = Una, Ray |genre = [[Drama]] |setting = Office break room |subject = An uneasy reunion between a woman and a middle-aged man fifteen years after he sexually abused her when she was twelve |premiere = 2005 |place = [[Edinburgh International Festival|Edinburgh Festival]]
Edinburgh, Scotland |orig_lang = English |web = }} '''''Blackbird''''' is a play written in 2005 by Scottish playwright [[David Harrower]]. It was inspired in part by the crimes of [[sex offender]] [[Toby Studebaker]], and depicts a young woman meeting a middle-aged man fifteen years after being sexually abused by him when she was twelve. David Harrower's ''Blackbird'' is not to be confused with the [[Adam Rapp]] play of the same name. ==Synopsis== At his workplace, 55-year-old Ray is shocked to be visited by a young woman, 27-year-old Una. Fifteen years earlier, they had a sexual relationship for three months when Una was 12 and Ray was 40; subsequently, Ray had been jailed for three years for [[statutory rape]].[https://newyorktheater.me/2016/03/18/blackbird-review-child-rape-15-years-later/ "''Blackbird'' Review: Child Rape, 15 Years Later"] by Jonathan Mandell, newyorktheater.me, 18 March 2016 Ultimately, they ran off together, and, while Ray was taking time to compose himself after realizing what he had just done, he left her alone in a motel room. She got worried and left to find him, which led to both of them frantically searching for one another and raising suspicions within the small coastal town where they were staying. Eventually, a couple out walking their dog took Una in and called the police after learning why she was there. Ray was then arrested and imprisoned. Upon his release, he managed to establish a reasonably successful new life under another name, but Una recognized him in a photograph and tracked him down. Ray takes Una to the office break room, where the two engage in a long and difficult confrontation involving Una's continuing struggles to understand and come to terms with the abuse and her intensely conflicting emotions, which pivot between anger, curiosity, confusion, and even a persistent attachment to Ray, whom Una loved – and she believed that he loved her. The fearful Ray, who is himself trying to forget the past and the potential feelings he had for Una, parries her demanding questions and descriptions of her feelings and experiences, all the while uncertain of her intentions. ==Film adaptation== A film adaptation of the play titled ''[[Una (film)|Una]]'' premiered in September 2016 at the [[Telluride Film Festival]]. The film stars [[Rooney Mara]] as Una and [[Ben Mendelsohn]] as Ray.{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/rooney-mara-ben-mendelsohn-star-746600|title=Rooney Mara and Ben Mendelsohn to Star in ''Blackbird''|publisher=Indiewire.com|first=David|last=Rooney|date=5 November 2014|accessdate=17 February 2016}} ==Productions== ''Blackbird'' was commissioned by the [[Edinburgh International Festival]], with a 2005 premiere at the festival, directed by [[Peter Stein]]. In February 2006, it opened at the [[West End theatre|West End]] [[Albery Theatre]] with [[Roger Allam]] and [[Jodhi May]].Fisher, Philip.{{cite web|url=http://www.britishtheatreguide.info/reviews/blackbird-rev.htm/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-11-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111117211033/http://britishtheatreguide.info/reviews/blackbird-rev.htm |archivedate=17 November 2011 |df=dmy }} ''Blackbird'', The British Theatre Guide, May 2006 In September 2006, it was well received in Stockholm at Dramaten ([[Royal Dramatic Theatre]]), in a co-production with [[Helsingborg City Theatre]], directed by Eva Dahlman; with Göran Stangertz and Anna Björk.Schwartz, Neil.[http://www.expressen.se/1.420900/] Strömförande kontakt, Expressen, 18 September 2006Gustafsson, Asnnika.{{cite web |url=http://sydsvenskan.se/kultur-och-nojen/article210895.ece/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-11-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120722162857/http://sydsvenskan.se/kultur-och-nojen/article210895.ece/ |archivedate=22 July 2012 |df=dmy-all }} ''Blackbird'' – en svart roll för Stangertz, Sydsvenskan, 17 January 2007Granath, Sara.[http://www.svd.se/kulturnoje/scen/artikel_353618.svd?voted=1256092140940/] Ett overgrepp pa nytt, SvD, 11 October 2007 (updated) In the spring of 2007, the play had simultaneous American premieres by the [[Manhattan Theatre Club]] ([[off-Broadway]]) and at [[American Conservatory Theater]] in San Francisco. The New York production was directed by [[Joe Mantello]],Sommer, Elyse.[http://www.curtainup.com/blackbirdny.html/] A CurtainUp Review: ''Blackbird'' – CurtainUp, April 2007 and featured [[Jeff Daniels]] and [[Alison Pill]] in the lead roles. In April 2008, the play was revived by David Grindley at the [[Rose Theatre, Kingston]], prior to a national tour of the UK.Thaxter, John.{{cite web|url=http://www.britishtheatreguide.info/reviews/blackbirdtour-rev.htm/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-11-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111117203104/http://britishtheatreguide.info/reviews/blackbirdtour-rev.htm |archivedate=17 November 2011 |df=dmy }} ''Blackbird'' – The British Theatre Guide, April 2008 In March 2008, the play opened in Mumbai, India, starring Indian film and theatre veterans [[Akash Khurana]] and [[Shernaz Patel]]. This Akvarious production was also later presented in Bangalore and in New Delhi. Shernaz Patel went on to win the award for Best Actress, for her portrayal of Una, at the 2010 Mahindra Excellence in Theatre Awards.Nair, Nandini.[http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-features/tp-fridayreview/beyond-black-and-white/article658344.ece "Beyond black and white"], ''The Hindu'', 8 May 2009 A 2016 [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] revival was mounted at the [[Belasco Theatre]] on 5 February 2016 (37 previews), and opened officially on 10 March (through 11 June, 108 performances), starring [[Michelle Williams (actress)|Michelle Williams]] and Jeff Daniels. It was directed by Joe Mantello.Viagas, Robert. [http://www.playbill.com/news/article/blackbird-starring-jeff-daniels-and-michelle-williams-arrives-on-broadway-tonight-384604 "''Blackbird'', Starring Jeff Daniels and Michelle Williams, Now in Broadway Previews"], ''[[Playbill]]'', 5 February 2016 It received critical praise.[https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2016/mar/10/blackbird-review-michelle-williams-and-jeff-daniels-stun-in-abuse-drama "Michelle Williams and Jeff Daniels stun in abuse drama"] by Alexis Soloski, ''[[The Guardian]]'', 11 March 2016 ''Blackbird'' had its [[South Korea]]n run on October 13 to November 13, 2016 at the DCF Daemyung Culture Factory Theater in [[Seoul]]'s [[Jongno District]]. [[Cho Jae-hyun]] portrayed Ray while [[Chae Soo-bin]] and {{Interlanguage link multi|Ok Ja-yeon|ko|3=옥자연}} were alternates in the role of Una.[http://m.entertain.naver.com/read?oid=382&aid=0000520905 채수빈, 연극 ‘블랙버드’ 관객 호평 속 마무리][http://news.donga.com/3/07/20160901/80088022/2 조재현, 美 브로드웨이 흥행작 연극 ‘블랙 버드’ 공연] In 2017, from 7 April to 7 May, the Spanish version of the play was staged in Madrid at El Pavón Teatro Kamikaze. Prior to this, it had toured several Spanish cities (Avilés, A Coruña, Ourense, Barakaldo and Seville). It starred [[Irene Escolar]] (as Una) and José Luis Torrijo (as Ray) and was directed by Carlota Ferrerr. ==Awards and nominations== *2006 [[Critics' Awards for Theatre in Scotland]] for Best New Play *2007 [[Laurence Olivier Award for Best New Play]] *2016 [[Tony Award for Best Revival of a Play]] nomination *2016 [[Tony Award for Best Actor in a Play]] (Jeff Daniels) nomination *2016 [[Tony Award for Best Actress in a Play]] (Michelle Williams) nomination ==References== ==Further reading== *{{cite book|last=Harrower|first=David|title=Blackbird|edition=First|location=London|publisher=Faber & Faber|year=2005|isbn=0-571-23080-6}} ==External links== * [https://charlierose.com/videos/28046?autoplay=true Actors Jeff Daniels and Michelle Williams discuss the revival of David Harrower's acclaimed 2005 play, ''Blackbird''], ''[[Charlie Rose (TV series)|Charlie Rose]]'' {{OlivierAward Play 2001–2025}} [[Category:2005 plays]] [[Category:Broadway plays]] [[Category:Off-Broadway plays]] [[Category:Laurence Olivier Award-winning plays]] [[Category:Scottish plays]] [[Category:West End plays]] [[Category:One-act plays]] [[Category:Two-handers]] [[Category:British plays adapted into films]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox organisation | name = The British Academy of {{nowrap|Stage & Screen Combat}} | image = British Academy Of Stage & Screen Combat.gif | image_border = | size = frameless | alt = <!-- alt text; see [[WP:ALT]] --> | caption = The British Academy Of Stage & Screen Combat (BASSC) logo | map = <!-- optional --> | msize = <!-- map size, optional, default 250px --> | malt = <!-- map alt text --> | mcaption = <!-- optional --> | abbreviation = BASSC | predecessor = {{nowrap|Society of British Fight Directors}} | successor = | formation = {{start date|1993}} | extinction = <!-- date of extinction, optional --> | type = Academy | purpose = Organisation for the tuition and development of [[stage combat]] for [[theatre]], [[television]] and [[feature film]] | location = London, United Kingdom | coords = <!-- Coordinates of location using a coordinates template --> | leader_title = President | leader_name = Janet Lawson | leader_title2 = Vice President | leader_name2 = Taylor Hohman | leader_title3 = Secretary | leader_name3 = Andrei Zayats | leader_title4 = Treasurer | leader_name4 = Philip d'Orleans | key_people = {{collapsible list|expand = true | title = Master Teachers | Richard Ryan | Bret Yount | Jonathan Leverett | Philip d’Orléans | Roger Bartlett | John McFarland }} {{collapsible list|expand = true | title = Certified Teachers | Aaron Anderson | Marlon Bulger | Tiza Garland | Mark D. Guinn | Sam Kahn | Janet Lawson | Rob Leonard | Chris Main | Scot Mann | Rosa Nicolàs | Ian Prater | Kristo Salminen | Ronin Traynor | Enric Ortuno | Yarit Dor | Andrei Zayats | Taylor Hohman | Elizabeth Talbot| Zhenya Leverett | Nathaniel Marten }} | affiliations = <!-- if any --> | website = [http://www.bassc.org/ bassc.org] }}
The '''British Academy Of Stage & Screen Combat (BASSC)''' is a British organisation for the tuition and development of [[stage combat]] for [[theatre]],<ref>{{cite web|last=Levenson|first=E.|url=http://www.rblandmark.com/main.asp?SectionID=4&SubSectionID=4&ArticleID=1580&TM=83655.09|title=Putting the Fight in Julius Caesar|publisher=The Brookfield Landmark|year= 2005}}</ref> [[television]] and [[feature film]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0332452/fullcredits|title=Troy - Cast & Crew Credits|publisher= IMDB.com|year= 2004}}</ref>
==History== '''The British Academy Of Stage & Screen Combat (BASSC)''' has its roots in the now defunct [[Society of British Fight Directors]]. In the early to mid nineties the [[Society of British Fight Directors]] went through a transitional period, as its focus began to shift towards the teaching of Stage Combat. In 1996, the ''Society of British Fight Directors'' voted to change its name to [[The British Academy of Dramatic Combat (BADC).]]
''The British Academy of Stage & Screen Combat'' was formed in 1993,<ref>{{cite web|last=Marysia|first=K.|url=http://www.bassc.org/about/|title=BASSC About Us|publisher=BASSC|year=2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090609094631/http://bassc.org/about|archivedate=2009-06-09|df=}}</ref> many founding members being of the former ''S.B.F.D''. The organisation set about creating its current reputation as the invigorating and driving force behind stage combat in the United Kingdom.
In 1997, British Equity recognised the ''BASSC’s'' Advanced Certificate as a valid qualification for entry onto the Equity Fight Directors’ Training Scheme and, in 2001, the BASSC was appointed by the Equity Council for the training and assessment of Fight Directors candidates applying to join the Equity Fight Directors’ Register. The ''BASSC'' is currently respected, both nationally and internationally, as a provider of professional level stage combat training.
Richard Ryan<ref>{{cite web|last=Ryan|first=R.|url=http://www.stagefight.com/|title= Richard Ryan Official Website|publisher=Stagefight.com|year= 2001}}</ref> was appointed the first Master Teacher of the BASSC. Since then he has gone on to become an established Hollywood Fight Director. His film credits include: [[Sherlock Holmes (2009 film)|Sherlock Holmes]], [[Troy (film)|Troy]], [[The Dark Knight (film)|The Dark Knight]], [[Stardust (2007 film)|Stardust]], [[Ironclad (film)|Ironclad]], [[The Eagle (2011 film)|The Eagle]], [[The Last Legion]], [[Fallen (1998 film)|Fallen]] & [[The Hammer of The Gods (film)|The Hammer of The Gods]]. As well as television & theatre, his work extends as far as [[video games]]; Notably, he was the Fight/Combat Consultant for the best-selling [[Xbox 360]] game [[Fable 2]] from [[Lionhead Studios]].
==Today== ''BASSC'' teachers can be found at many leading UK Drama & Arts Schools, including the [[Royal Academy of Dramatic Art]], [http://www.bcu.ac.uk/conservatoire/acting Royal Birmingham Conservatoire of Music and Acting] , [[East 15 Acting School]], [[London college of Music]], [[Royal Academy of Music]], [[Central School of Speech and Drama]], [[Italia_Conti_drama_school|Italia Conti]], [[Guildhall School of Music & Drama]], [[Drama Studio London|Drama Studio]], [[Fourth Monkey Theatre Company]], [[British American Drama Academy]] and the [[City Lit]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Wild|first=J.|url= http://www.thecnj.com/camden/082406/edu082406_01.htm |title=Taking a swipe at the traditional subjects|publisher= Camden News Journal|year= 2007}}</ref> Classes and Workshops are also held across the UK and are open to the public and other actor/combatants.<ref>{{cite web|last=Girard|first= D.|url=http://regentbackstage.blogspot.com/2009/02/virginia-beach-bash-09-fighting-for.html |title=Virginia Beach Bash '09: Fighting for Film and TV!|publisher= Recent Bacstage|year= 2009}}</ref>
''BASSC'' now has training schemes in place which allow for development from Actor/Combatant to Certified Teacher as well as assessment and training of Fight Directors for the Equity register.
==Fight Performance Tests== For Actor/Combatants, the ''BASSC'' offers 'Fight Performance Tests' in core stage combat weapon systems from the BASSC syllabus.
The test requires actors to perform a dramatic scene containing a stage combat fight, choreographed and taught by a ''BASSC'' certified teacher. Students are marked on both stage combat technique and the acting within the scene. Based upon marks the awards available are: Fail, Pass & Pass with Distinction.
Below is a list of the BASSC core weapon syllabus:
Weapons Systems *Unarmed Combat *Single Rapier *Rapier & Dagger *Broadsword *Quarterstaff *Sword & Shield *Smallsword *Knife *Rapier & Cloak
==References== <references/>
==External links== * [http://www.bassc.org BASSC Website] * [http://www.stagefight.com Richard Ryan] * [https://www.movingbodyarts.com/ Moving Body Arts] * [http://independentdrama.com/ Independent Drama]

{{EngvarB|date=October 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} [[File:Camrose Trophy for Home International Bridge Championships.jpg|thumb|right|The Camrose Trophy]]
The '''Camrose Trophy''' or "The Camrose" is an annual [[Contract bridge|bridge]] competition among open teams representing the [[home nations]] of Great Britain and Ireland: England ([[English Bridge Union|EBU]]), [[Northern Ireland]] (NIBU), [[Republic of Ireland]] (CBAI), [[Scotland]] (SBU) and [[Wales]] (WBU). As such it is the [[Glossary of contract bridge terms#open|open]] [[Glossary of contract bridge terms#team|teams-of-four]] component of the "Home Internationals" organised by [[Bridge Great Britain]].<ref name=history>[http://www.bridgewebs.com/bgb/Brief%20History.htm "Home Internationals: a brief history"]. By [[Patrick Jourdain]]. Bridge Great Britain. Retrieved 17 December 2013. "The Camrose" is the open teams event.</ref>
[[William Berry, 1st Viscount Camrose|Lord Camrose]], owner of ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'', donated the trophy in 1936 and it was first contested in 1937. The original trophy has been lost and replaced. Because of [[World War II]] the series was interrupted mid-way in 1939 and not resumed until 1946, yet the Camrose is the world's most-played international bridge series.<ref name=history />
Beside "The Camrose" (Open flight), the Home Bridge Internationals include annual series for Women from 1950, Juniors from 1971, Under-19 from 1990, and Seniors from 2008.<ref name=history />
==Structure== Since 2007 there have been six rather than five teams in the competition, to avoid having one team sit out each round. From 2007 to 2009 the sixth team was the defending champion, so there were two teams from the previous year's winning nation. England's second team won in 2009, when it was the final-round host by coincidence.<ref name=history/> Since then by design the sixth team is a second team from the final-round host nation, which follows a five-year cycle from Northern Ireland in 2010 to England in 2014. That second representative is named for the national bridge federation; thus "Wales" and "Welsh Bridge Union" both entered in 2011.<ref name=history />
Since 2005 a [[round-robin tournament|double round-robin]] is scheduled on two weekends.<ref name=history /> With six teams, each weekend comprises five rounds of three head-to-head matches, a single round-robin. A match is now 32 {{gcb|deal|deals}} scored at [[Duplicate bridge#IMP scoring|IMPs]] and converted to {{gcb|victory|victory points (VP)}}.<ref name=event2011>[http://www.bridgewebs.com/bgb/Camrose%20Results%202011.pdf "Camrose Trophy 2011"]. Bridge Great Britain. Retrieved 17 December 2013.</ref> So every team plays 320 deals in the entire event, 64 against each of its rivals. Before 2005, the teams played head-to-head matches over five weekends.
Before 2007 there were simply five national teams, or four during the 48-year absence by the [[Republic of Ireland]] from 1951 to 1998.<ref name=history />
==Results== England won both of the completed pre-war and the first 17 post-war contests, through 1962. Only England and Scotland were winners in the 56 renditions before year 2000, including England–Scotland ties 1972 and 1973. Ireland first won in 2000 and won four straight beginning 2005.<ref name=winners>[http://www.bridgewebs.com/bgb/Camrose%20Winners%20List.htm "Archives: Camrose Trophy Winners"]. Bridge Great Britain. Retrieved 17 December 2013. See also sibling pages.</ref> Wales won its first Camrose in 2011, but now England are again dominant, winning six times in the last eight years. The 2016 contest was won by England.
===Winners by nation=== The competition has been completed 73 times up to 2016.<ref name=winners/> There was an outright winner on each occasion except for 1972 and 1973, when England and Scotland tied for first place.<!--not the 1961 tie that [ref name=winners] lists--> England's count includes a win in 2009 by its second team, "English Bridge Union".<ref name=winners />
{| class="wikitable sortable" ! Nation || Outright wins ||Tied wins <!-- [ref name=winners] lists three England-Scotland ties 1961 1972 1973 and reports a correct count of its list; [ref name=history] reports two ties 1972 1973 and a count that is inconsistent 2014-02-15 we report two ties and a correct count given our list; thus we match neither published count --> |- | [[England]] | align=center|51 | align=center|2 |- | [[Scotland]] | align=center|13 | align=center|2 |- | [[Republic of Ireland]] | align=center|7 | align=center|0 |- | [[Wales]] | align=center|1 | align=center|0 |- | [[Northern Ireland]] | align=center|0 | align=center|0 |}
===Winners by year=== Three times recently (*), the winners have been one of two entries from their countries, namely "Ireland" 2008, "EBU" 2009 (English Bridge Union), and "Wales" 2011. They were the defending champion team, the England "B" team, and the Wales "A" team respectively. Their compatriots were "Hosts Ireland", "England", and "WBU" (Welsh Bridge Union).<ref name=history /><ref name=scores>[http://www.bridgewebs.com/bgb/Camrose%20Results%202010.htm "Past Results: Camrose Results 2010"]. Bridge Great Britain. Retrieved 17 December 2013. Sibling pages give 2003 to 2009 and 2011 to 2013 scores and more.</ref>
